body_html:
@asimshankar — Yes, it does help.

I think what's confusing me is the notion of running or evaluating operations. But now I think I see.

Functions like tf.cos add a node to the graph and return an edge, and when I run or eval I'm tugging on the edge and that, rather than directly "running" the operation, is what invokes the operation (and so on for any edges it tugs on in turn).

In effect, if you will, I don't make the machinery go by pressing a button on the op (which is what I naively expect), but by drawing from the pipe that comes out of it; and its that action that fills all the pipes in the graph with values. That's why I'm handed back a pipes (tf.Tensor): everything operates by tapping them, not the operations they emerge from.

(I'm still a bit puzzled about this though — and the answer given — which is what sent me down the road to this misunderstanding in the first place.)

body:
@asimshankar — Yes, it does help. 

I think what's confusing me is the notion of running or evaluating operations. But now I think I see. 

Functions like `tf.cos` add a node to the graph and return an edge, and when I `run` or `eval` I'm tugging on the edge and _that_, rather than directly "running" the operation, is what invokes the operation (and so on for any edges it tugs on in turn).

In effect, if you will, I don't make the machinery go by pressing a button on the op (which is what I naively expect), but by drawing from the pipe that comes out of it; and its that action that fills all the pipes in the graph with values. That's why I'm handed back a pipes (`tf.Tensor`): everything operates by tapping them, not the operations they emerge from.

(I'm still a bit [puzzled about this](https://stackoverflow.com/q/44335033/656912) though — and [the answer](https://stackoverflow.com/a/44335999/656912) given — which is what sent me down the road to this misunderstanding in the first place.)
